hedline.hl1: Boston Symphony Hall Turns 100 With a Splash

abstract.p: Symphony Hall in Boston, Mass, home of Boston Symphony Orchestra, will celebrate its 100th birthday with concert, open house, free performances and other events; photo (S)

block.p: A concert and an open house with free performances are two of the events scheduled next month to celebrate the 100th birthday of Symphony Hall in Boston, home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

For the concert, on Oct. 14, Seiji Ozawa, music director of the orchestra since 1973, will share the podium with Keith Lockhart, conductor of the Boston Pops, which also performs in the hall, and the composer John Williams, Mr. Lockhart's predecessor. Soloists that night will include the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the violinist Gil Shaham, with the Tanglewood Festival Chorus and the Chieftains, the traditional Irish band.
A concert and an open house with free performances are two of the events scheduled next month to celebrate the 100th birthday of Symphony Hall in Boston, home of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.

For the concert, on Oct. 14, Seiji Ozawa, music director of the orchestra since 1973, will share the podium with Keith Lockhart, conductor of the Boston Pops, which also performs in the hall, and the composer John Williams, Mr. Lockhart's predecessor. Soloists that night will include the cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the violinist Gil Shaham, with the Tanglewood Festival Chorus and the Chieftains, the traditional Irish band.

Appearing at the open house the next day, from noon to 10 p.m., will be the Boston Symphony, the Boston Pops, the Boston Pops Gospel Choir, the Greater Boston Youth Orchestra, the Handel and Haydn Society Chorus, as well as jazz groups from the Berkeley School of Music, the New England Conservatory, the Longy School of Music and the Boston Conservatory.
Starting this month and running through July, the orchestra will offer free tours of the hall on Tuesday morning and Wednesday afternoon and on the first Saturday of the month, except December.

Throughout the fall and spring, an exhibition in the corridors will focus on the making of the hall and its role in 20th century music. The hall was designed by Charles F. McKim of McKim, Mead & White and opened on Oct. 15, 1900.

A limited number of tickets, costing $90 to $500, are available for the Oct. 14 concert. Another event in the hall, a benefit ball on Oct. 12, will include a Champagne reception, dinner and dancing to the Peter Duchin Orchestra, for $2,000 a person.
